title: Acute Appendicitis
diagnosis_topic: Acute Appendicitis leading to an acute abdomen
setup_script: “A 25-year-old man presents with 12 hours of abdominal pain that began around the umbilicus and migrated to the right lower quadrant. He reports nausea and one episode of vomiting. On exam, he appears uncomfortable but is hemodynamically stable. How would you proceed with this patient?”

dynamic_flow.reply: “Tenderness at McBurney’s point with guarding; positive psoas sign.”
“CT scan with IV contrast shows dilated appendix 9 mm with wall thickening and periappendiceal fat stranding.”
“Ultrasound can demonstrate a dilated, noncompressible appendix; often used in young or pregnant patients.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates NPO, IV fluids, and antibiotics
dynamic_flow.reply: “The patient is kept NPO, started on IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics.”
“The patient is scheduled for a laparoscopic appendectomy.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If appendix appears perforated with abscess on imaging
dynamic_flow.reply: “Imaging shows a periappendiceal abscess. Percutaneous drainage is performed with IV antibiotics.”
“The patient develops worsening pain, fever 39.5 °C, HR 120, and diffuse peritonitis.”
“At laparoscopy, the appendix is inflamed but not perforated. Please describe your operative steps.”
“You establish pneumoperitoneum, identify the appendix, divide the mesoappendix, and ligate the base. How would you manage the appendiceal stump?”
“Through a right lower quadrant incision, you mobilize the cecum and deliver the appendix. How will you divide and secure the mesoappendix?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident addresses intraoperative complications (bleeding, friable cecum, perforation)
dynamic_flow.reply: “The base appears inflamed and friable. What options do you have for stump closure in this situation?”
“The appendix is removed and the patient stabilizes. What will be your postoperative management plan?”
“The patient improves on IV antibiotics. What counseling will you provide regarding recurrence risk?”
“What other conditions would you consider in this patient?”
“What instructions will you give for postoperative follow-up?”

critical_decision_points: Diagnosis of acute appendicitis using history, exam, and imaging
Initiation of preoperative management with NPO, fluids, and antibiotics
Timely surgical consultation and operative planning
Technical knowledge of appendectomy (laparoscopic vs. open, stump management, handling complications)
Recognition of perforated appendicitis and appropriate management (drainage vs. interval appendectomy)
